name: Jerusalem
type: Ancient walled city - religious, political, and commercial center
time_period: 30-135 CE (primary narrative focus); also 26-36 CE (Crucifixion era)
narrative_significance: THE central setting of the entire novel; where the Spear is held, where the Crucifixion occurs, where the network operates, where the apocalyptic conflict unfolds
story_arcs: Present in ALL parts; central to Parts 1-9 (30-70 CE), aftermath of destruction in Part 9 (70-135 CE)
one_line_description: The heart of 1st century Judea—a city of pilgrimage, power, and profound tension under Roman occupation.

physical_description.title: Physical Description & Layout
physical_description.geographic_setting: Mountain stronghold in Judean highlands; built on series of steep hills separated by valleys. Approximately 1 mile per side when fully walled; population 50,000-100,000 during major festivals.
physical_description.scale: Semi-arid, hot, rocky; rare but heavy winter rains; elevation ~2,500 feet above sea level. Four main gates: Damascus Gate (north), Jaffa Gate (west), Dung Gate (south), Golden Gate (east).
physical_description.natural_features: Mount Moriah (Temple Mount), Mount of Olives to the east, Hinnom Valley to the south, Kidron Valley to the east; natural springs including Gihon Spring. Highly varied elevation; Temple Mount highest point, Kidron Valley lowest.
physical_description.primary_structures: Second Temple Complex (Mount Moriah), Fortress of Antonia (NW corner of Temple Mount), The Praetorium, Royal Palaces (Western Hill), Sanhedrin Chamber, City Walls (three concentric walls), Gates, Residential Houses, Market Areas, Water Systems (Gihon Spring, cisterns). Herodian period architecture—massive stone construction, predominantly pale to golden limestone.

sensory_details.title: Sensory Details & Atmosphere
sensory_details.overall_impression: A city of contrasts—golden temple gleaming in sunlight, narrow shadowy streets, constant noise and activity, incense and sacrifice mingling with dust and crowding.
sensory_details.dominant_colors: Pale golden limestone walls (especially at sunrise/sunset), blue Mediterranean sky, deep shadows in narrow streets, green vegetation in Gethsemane, blood-red soil, white priestly garments
sensory_details.signature_visual: Golden roof of Temple gleams in sunlight; massive stone blocks; from Temple Mount, can see Kidron Valley and Mount of Olives.
sensory_details.lighting: Intense sunlight at midday casting sharp shadows; golden light at sunrise/sunset on the temple and walls; dim, shadowy streets in the densely built lower city; complete darkness at night in narrow alleys.
sensory_details.essential_atmosphere: Constant noise during daytime—marketplace haggling, bleating animals, shouted conversations in Hebrew/Aramaic/Greek. Incense from Temple permeates upper city; blood and butchering from temple sacrifices during festival seasons.

historical_context.title: Historical & Cultural Context
historical_context.historical_significance: Center of Jewish faith, politics, and culture for over 1,000 years; site of ancient temples; focus of worldwide Jewish pilgrimage; politically significant to Rome; location of Christian faith's foundational event (Crucifixion).
historical_context.cultural_importance: Home of Second Temple—holiest site in Judaism. Required pilgrimage site for major festivals (Passover, Pentecost, Sukkot). Sanhedrin meets here—highest Jewish legal and religious authority. Hub of scholarship, legal interpretation, religious innovation.
historical_context.symbolic_meaning: Jerusalem = the City of God, the Holy City, Zion. Represents Jewish independence and religious freedom. Symbol of hope for restoration and redemption. Focus of messianic expectations.

primary.name: Cassius Longinus Mercator
primary.role: Roman centurion; primary residence in Jerusalem; commands troops in Fortress of Antonia; present at Crucifixion (Mount Golgotha); witnessed the spear; central to story's opening

primary.name: Malchus bar Eleazar
primary.role: Disciple of Jesus; present at major events (Crucifixion, post-resurrection encounters); later becomes guardian of the Spear; leads network from Jerusalem

primary.name: Hannah of Samaria
primary.role: Network coordinator; operates refugee network from Jerusalem; moves through city identifying those needing help

primary.name: Pontius Pilate
primary.role: Roman prefect; primary residence in Jerusalem; conducts Crucifixion trial; seat of political authority

primary.name: Joseph Caiaphas
primary.role: High Priest; seat of religious authority; central to Sanhedrin; instrumental in Jesus's trial

key_scenes.title: Key Scenes & Events
events: The Crucifixion (30 or 33 CE, Mount Golgotha): Jesus executed by Roman crucifixion; spear pierces Jesus's side; cosmic light erupts; foundational event for Christian faith and our narrative
Post-Resurrection Appearances: Jesus appears to disciples multiple times in Jerusalem; establishes community of believers
Pentecost (50 days after Passover): Holy Spirit descends on disciples in Jerusalem; Christian community begins
Early Christian Community Growth (30-70 CE): Gradual growth of Christian believers; increasing tension with religious authorities
Jewish Revolt (66 CE): Armed rebellion against Rome begins in Jerusalem; Jewish factions seize control
Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE): Roman legions under Titus besiege city; months of starvation and violence
Destruction (70 CE): Roman forces systematically destroy city; Temple destroyed; massive death toll
